docs.text: ♪ The Evolutionary Principle * A new philosophy * by Reto Andrin Weber Genre: Philosophy Target group: Philosophy-interested; advanced lay people as well as experts. Brief summary: I describe the observation that all we can perceive and describe are patterns. I show logical laws that are subject to all patterns. These laws allow a new look at old questions. Thus the question of God, the question of truth and the question of good and evil is merely a question of a pattern. And the new perspective offers a new perspective on these fundamental questions. It lets us combine two worlds that were otherwise not thought together in philosophy (except in psychoanalysis): irrational spirituality with the rational. We will see what world view will last more than time; and how they have to change in the future. We will also see what compromises we have to deal with in our view on the truth. The whole is rounded off with a few practical lessons. Because the newly gained view prefers a pragmatic and open view of the world. It can provide a basis for rapprochements with other thinkers, gain a sense of suffering, justify a metaphysics free from assumptions, evaluate different ethics and much more. In the whole book, I try to deal with the readers as honestly as possible and to disclose my strategy behind the formulations. My approach is fundamentally different from what I have read so far, so hopefully other thinkers can fascinate. In the whole book, my inner struggle between atheism and Christianity is reflected. However, representatives of both directions will take Anstoss on the book. The ones will say I reduce God to an imagined idea and the others that I support and spread untruths. This will always be the case if you do something new. The content in this book is dense as I abhor long-drawn books. These are wasting my time. So I hope I don't waste yours. Widmung: This book is dedicated to all those who never get the chance to write a book. Never read the thoughts of our great thinkers. Never experience love. Never experience sadness. Never bring their vision. Never spray blessings. Shame for all the Nobel Peace Prizes that will never be forgiven. Shame for all the inventions that are never made. Shame on all the poems that are never written. Patterns, their laws *and where they can be found * Introduction A large number of thinkers wanted to invent a new philosophy and believed to have made it. So why do I have to write such a book again? The confidence advance I need is ridiculously large. The probability of success for a successful book vanishingly small. However, if one is convinced that one would have found something big, it is almost a duty to pursue this idea. I was wondering if the idea was new. I discussed. I dealt with the strongest version of the counter arguments. It usually follows that the idea is not new and/or wrong. But once an idea has survived all these stages, it is now just as a duty to bring this idea to paper. If I want to find out if it is new and good, I have to do this in a language that is as convincing as possible to tie the reader. It is also a duty to present the idea as clearly as possible; self-confident, but also vulnerable, in the sense that everyone should see them and tear them apart if they are not true. But why read? It will probably always be a secret why an author's first work has ever been read. There was no reason. Don't be the selfless who are ready to read new books. Although they know that the overwhelming part of the work they will read is unusable. But these people are the catalyst for progress in society. It's you who make a book from a Word document. But why should others read it? On the one hand, I keep thinking of Nietzsche. Nietzsche comments in «Everyone of Good and Evil» that the truth is abused only as an argument to force one's own view to the other. He presented a world image that focuses on power and thus suggests: "What is the value of something good if it does not exceed time." I keep following this thought and we will strike things that may not be true, but are good or at least useful. I prefer wisdom to truth. But don't worry. I still argue clearly and precisely. My reflections are more meaningful than some philosophy, which is operated under the cover of ‹Truth-finding›. While materialism and dualism are assumptions for me that say too much and say too little, I will present a way of thinking that can be combined with both, but is also concretely useful. I will show concepts that have changed my views sustainably. This approach allows, without having to throw overboard your own convictions, to take over the assertions of the opposite side of your own thinking. So it allows a young eagle to think about evolution, with a tolerable amount of cognitive dissonance. On the contrary, for example, atheists can adapt religious truths more literally. And both do not need to turn to the opposite. In addition to this way of thinking, which, as I said, optimizes wisdom and not truth, I present a theory that makes complex and confusing processes in the world understandable. It helps to identify and influence directions in the development of systems. Therefore, if someone is interested in understanding and changing their own life, that of the family, their quarters or their country, this book offers pragmatic approaches. I strongly believe that it offers the most effective way to change, which makes it possible to think fundamentally about systems. So that you know where our journey goes and you don't forget why we do this now, I present the content of the book here. We develop a theory that can generally be applied to everything that exists. So a kind of natural law that the whole world is governed by. Regardless of whether these are beings, natural laws, planets or even God. Everything depends on this law. ( An ontological law )) After that you can see the world with new eyes. And we can reconsider old questions. ( A new glasses ) Then we consider the concept of 'truth'. For our new glasses throws the foundations of reasonable thinking. That is why we need to reconcile what it means to be true. ( value of truth ) After truth we dare to ethics; So what is good and bad. From our point of view, a path for existing ethics will emerge where they are to develop. So a meta-ethic will crystallize out. ( An ethics of stability )) We will see that rationalism is too naive and we need fist rules and other simplifications to get clear in this world. ( The complexity reduction as a necessary ethical act )) We will develop ways to integrate other ways of thinking into our own without having to step your own with feet. ( The validity of different complexity reductions ) After all these considerations, we will discover new approaches to other thinkers and illustrate this in the question of God. This is then independent of the current beliefs. ( The question of God ) And finally we use the learned concepts to answer old questions in a new way. ( Musterary Lessons )) An ontological law This is a book for ambitious philosophical laymen, as I myself am one. I therefore declare the most important terms whenever such occurs. It is my concern that I can convey my idea as precisely as necessary, but also as simple as possible. I try not to define mathematically or philosophically, but to explain it in a comprehensible manner. Defining, distances itself from the natural language and impedes intuition. However, the intuition is the most important tool for keeping and processing information. But the intuition is always uncomfortable. Words and ideas are ambiguous and the meaning will never be completely clear. Who mathematically defined, tries to create a clear language that hardly deserves to be called language, but calculus. Because only abstract things are clear enough that they can be defined. The empirical world is blurred. In every logical language (mathematics and logic) there is no place for reality. She can speak about herself, but as soon as mathematics wants to refer to the real world as a simple concept as ‹two›, she fails. Mathematics claims, for example: «1 = 1» But in the real world, an apple is never exactly the same as the other apple. Therefore, two apples are never like two apples. Mathematics is only interesting insofar as we see that things in the real world behave as mathematical things. For example, we can count apples. But as soon as we lose the reference of mathematics to reality, it is useless and worthless (1) . So I do not escape here in the idealism of Platon or in the mathematical language, in order to make the statements precise and irrevocable. Because even though they were indispensable, they would also be irrelevant. I'm trying a lot more about a language game. I see this book and language in general not as a tool to find ‹truth›, but a natural way of interacting with the world; to grasp and change them. I try to plant thoughts in the heads, which then themselves should carry seeds and multiply. Whether this thought is true in a metaphysical sense, I do not dare to assert and is also irrelevant for this desired dynamic of the seed train. Because whether an idea is spreading, it is limited to doing something with the degree of truth of the idea. But I try to shape the thoughts in the minds of the readers as exactly as possible. Therefore, paradoxically, it is always necessary to explain things exactly, even to define. But the aim of the speeches is exclusively to influence the thoughts of the readers. Mathematics and logic are useful for this. But I do not use them as a self-interest, but as a tool of thought and thus world manipulation. So mathematics is only here to sharpen intuition. And if the joy of reading has passed on to you now before loud mathematics and logic. As mathematical as it may sound, it will not be. So we can start with the actual topic. The trigger for this book was my journey into philosophy and the related thoughts. It folded up a world in my head, from which I neither read nor heard. And these thoughts were revolutionary for my personal life and changed my understanding of the great questions of life: "Is it a God?" or "What is matter?". But also more fundamental: "What is at all?" or better said: "What can be recognized as ‹seiend›?". The first questions may still be considered legitimate as a philosophically uninterested person, but the last one hardly. But it was precisely these questions (in this order) that have put my worldview on the head. For it is tempting to think, it would be clear what distinguishes something existing from something non-existing. Precisely formulated, people are not concerned with the question of what is being done, but: what is being recognized? I mean «recognize»; grasping something through language or in thought. Can we recognize God? And if so, how? What would that mean? Let's start simpler: Can we recognize this book? ‹Klar. It's right in front of me› now you say. But what if you just dream? Keywords Descartes ‹I do not dream of such a boring theme. › So good. But then I had to dare a journey of thought. I thought: What can you see? It's not just physical objects like the chair I'm sitting on. I also realize that I'm married, although that's nothing physical. I recognize my role in the world, my profession, my social status, my wealth, my intellect, my emotions, my irrationality. I know a lot. But are there also non-recognizable things? Things exist but are inaccessible to us. In my computer science study, I stumbled on such things and this has shocked and fascinated me. There were actually (in this example) numbers that cannot be described. There will never be a numerical system, an artificial intelligence that can all represent these numbers. And there are even infinitely many of them. Small numbers are available and large. I can't call it, because then I would have recognized it, but we know that there are. I tried to follow this thought. What do you know? What is common to these things? It is not matter, because my profession is not matter. It is not the language, because the feelings were before the language. Thus, due to lack of alternatives, I came to the concept of the ‹Muster› . Patterns When I say 'Muster', very different things float through your head. Patterns may mean something nice to draw. Geometric figures that are in any regularity. Or someone comes from the intellectual corner and immediately thinks of regularity in nature. These then speak of a pattern when they notice the fact that all planets are not accidentally, but precisely circle around a sun in an ellipse. While the planets themselves are quite randomly in space, the orbit of the planets is by no means random. This ‹non-random› I mean when I talk about patterns. There are things that bear a simplicity in themselves as soon as they have been recognized. Let's consider a baby, for example. His world is small. It consists mainly of his mat, his bed and his mother. When the mother disappears, the world of the infant grows. He cries and expresses with all his abilities the abyss depth despair. When the mother is there and when not, is random for an infant and thus scary and cannot be understood. It must first get an idea that the mother is there, even if she is not felt or smelled. An abstract concept. However, it seems logical and banal to us, but it does not necessarily have to be that. This idea of the continuity of objects is eventually developed by the toddler. It is no longer disturbed when something disappears in a box. The disappearance and emergence of the mother were also much easier to understand and thus to withstand. It found a simplification for this situation, a pattern. This simplification is not intellectually understood. Also not in pictures or language. Rather narrative, so as a story. This story of the mother coming back is comforting. A confusing situation was made clear. An Muster was recognized in the behavior of the mother: it comes back. The pattern already existed before the child who recognized it. But only when it was recognized, it got the ability to calm down. Here is more precise what a pattern is. So that the idea takes shape in you as clearly as possible. Patterns are things that are recognizable, as already said. And what is all recognizable? A lot that can be perceived by the senses: a table, a person, the sky. But even more abstract things: love, joy, mourning. Or ideas like: justice and arbitration. Even more abstract things like: the number two, truth or peace. As you can see from these last examples: patterns are not just things you can perceive. You can't perceive the number two, but you know. She can't be found in the world. Nowhere in the world is the number two and if you destroy them then there is no more the concept of duality. docs.text: Genre: Philosophy Target group: Philosophy-interested; advanced lay people as well as experts. Brief summary: I describe the observation that all we can perceive and describe are patterns. I show logical laws that are subject to all patterns. These laws allow a new look at old questions. Thus the question of God, the question of truth and the question of good and evil is merely a question of a pattern. And the new perspective offers a new perspective on these fundamental questions. It lets us combine two worlds that were otherwise not thought together in philosophy (except in psychoanalysis): irrational spirituality with the rational. We will see what world view will last more than time; and how they have to change in the future. We will also see what compromises we have to deal with in our view on the truth. The whole is rounded off with a few practical lessons. Because the newly gained view prefers a pragmatic and open view of the world. It can provide a basis for rapprochements with other thinkers, gain a sense of suffering, justify a metaphysics free from assumptions, evaluate different ethics and much more. In the whole book, I try to deal with the readers as honestly as possible and to disclose my strategy behind the formulations. My approach is fundamentally different from what I have read so far, so hopefully other thinkers can fascinate. In the whole book, my inner struggle between atheism and Christianity is reflected. However, representatives of both directions will take Anstoss on the book. The ones will say I reduce God to an imagined idea and the others that I support and spread untruths. This will always be the case if you do something new. The content in this book is dense as I abhor long-drawn books. These are wasting my time. So I hope I don't waste yours. Widmung: This book is dedicated to all those who never get the chance to write a book. Never read the thoughts of our great thinkers. Never experience love. Never experience sadness. Never bring their vision. Never spray blessings. Shame for all the Nobel Peace Prizes that will never be forgiven. Shame for all the inventions that are never made. Shame on all the poems that are never written.

*and where they can be found * Introduction A large number of thinkers wanted to invent a new philosophy and believed to have made it. So why do I have to write such a book again? The confidence advance I need is ridiculously large. The probability of success for a successful book vanishingly small. However, if one is convinced that one would have found something big, it is almost a duty to pursue this idea. I was wondering if the idea was new. I discussed. I dealt with the strongest version of the counter arguments. It usually follows that the idea is not new and/or wrong. But once an idea has survived all these stages, it is now just as a duty to bring this idea to paper. If I want to find out if it is new and good, I have to do this in a language that is as convincing as possible to tie the reader. It is also a duty to present the idea as clearly as possible; self-confident, but also vulnerable, in the sense that everyone should see them and tear them apart if they are not true. But why read? It will probably always be a secret why an author's first work has ever been read. There was no reason. Don't be the selfless who are ready to read new books. Although they know that the overwhelming part of the work they will read is unusable. But these people are the catalyst for progress in society. It's you who make a book from a Word document. But why should others read it? On the one hand, I keep thinking of Nietzsche. Nietzsche comments in «Everyone of Good and Evil» that the truth is abused only as an argument to force one's own view to the other. He presented a world image that focuses on power and thus suggests: "What is the value of something good if it does not exceed time." I keep following this thought and we will strike things that may not be true, but are good or at least useful. I prefer wisdom to truth. But don't worry. I still argue clearly and precisely. My reflections are more meaningful than some philosophy, which is operated under the cover of ‹Truth-finding›. While materialism and dualism are assumptions for me that say too much and say too little, I will present a way of thinking that can be combined with both, but is also concretely useful. I will show concepts that have changed my views sustainably. This approach allows, without having to throw overboard your own convictions, to take over the assertions of the opposite side of your own thinking. So it allows a young eagle to think about evolution, with a tolerable amount of cognitive dissonance. On the contrary, for example, atheists can adapt religious truths more literally. And both do not need to turn to the opposite. In addition to this way of thinking, which, as I said, optimizes wisdom and not truth, I present a theory that makes complex and confusing processes in the world understandable. It helps to identify and influence directions in the development of systems. Therefore, if someone is interested in understanding and changing their own life, that of the family, their quarters or their country, this book offers pragmatic approaches. I strongly believe that it offers the most effective way to change, which makes it possible to think fundamentally about systems. So that you know where our journey goes and you don't forget why we do this now, I present the content of the book here. We develop a theory that can generally be applied to everything that exists. So a kind of natural law that the whole world is governed by. Regardless of whether these are beings, natural laws, planets or even God. Everything depends on this law. ( An ontological law )) After that you can see the world with new eyes. And we can reconsider old questions. ( A new glasses ) Then we consider the concept of 'truth'. For our new glasses throws the foundations of reasonable thinking. That is why we need to reconcile what it means to be true. ( value of truth ) After truth we dare to ethics; So what is good and bad. From our point of view, a path for existing ethics will emerge where they are to develop. So a meta-ethic will crystallize out. ( An ethics of stability )) We will see that rationalism is too naive and we need fist rules and other simplifications to get clear in this world. ( The complexity reduction as a necessary ethical act )) We will develop ways to integrate other ways of thinking into our own without having to step your own with feet. ( The validity of different complexity reductions ) After all these considerations, we will discover new approaches to other thinkers and illustrate this in the question of God. This is then independent of the current beliefs. ( The question of God ) And finally we use the learned concepts to answer old questions in a new way. ( Musterary Lessons ))

docs.text: This is a book for ambitious philosophical laymen, as I myself am one. I therefore declare the most important terms whenever such occurs. It is my concern that I can convey my idea as precisely as necessary, but also as simple as possible. I try not to define mathematically or philosophically, but to explain it in a comprehensible manner. Defining, distances itself from the natural language and impedes intuition. However, the intuition is the most important tool for keeping and processing information. But the intuition is always uncomfortable. Words and ideas are ambiguous and the meaning will never be completely clear. Who mathematically defined, tries to create a clear language that hardly deserves to be called language, but calculus. Because only abstract things are clear enough that they can be defined. The empirical world is blurred. In every logical language (mathematics and logic) there is no place for reality. She can speak about herself, but as soon as mathematics wants to refer to the real world as a simple concept as ‹two›, she fails. Mathematics claims, for example: «1 = 1» But in the real world, an apple is never exactly the same as the other apple. Therefore, two apples are never like two apples. Mathematics is only interesting insofar as we see that things in the real world behave as mathematical things. For example, we can count apples. But as soon as we lose the reference of mathematics to reality, it is useless and worthless (1) . So I do not escape here in the idealism of Platon or in the mathematical language, in order to make the statements precise and irrevocable. Because even though they were indispensable, they would also be irrelevant. I'm trying a lot more about a language game. I see this book and language in general not as a tool to find ‹truth›, but a natural way of interacting with the world; to grasp and change them. I try to plant thoughts in the heads, which then themselves should carry seeds and multiply. Whether this thought is true in a metaphysical sense, I do not dare to assert and is also irrelevant for this desired dynamic of the seed train. Because whether an idea is spreading, it is limited to doing something with the degree of truth of the idea. But I try to shape the thoughts in the minds of the readers as exactly as possible. Therefore, paradoxically, it is always necessary to explain things exactly, even to define. But the aim of the speeches is exclusively to influence the thoughts of the readers. Mathematics and logic are useful for this. But I do not use them as a self-interest, but as a tool of thought and thus world manipulation. So mathematics is only here to sharpen intuition. And if the joy of reading has passed on to you now before loud mathematics and logic. As mathematical as it may sound, it will not be. So we can start with the actual topic. The trigger for this book was my journey into philosophy and the related thoughts. It folded up a world in my head, from which I neither read nor heard. And these thoughts were revolutionary for my personal life and changed my understanding of the great questions of life: "Is it a God?" or "What is matter?". But also more fundamental: "What is at all?" or better said: "What can be recognized as ‹seiend›?". The first questions may still be considered legitimate as a philosophically uninterested person, but the last one hardly. But it was precisely these questions (in this order) that have put my worldview on the head. For it is tempting to think, it would be clear what distinguishes something existing from something non-existing. Precisely formulated, people are not concerned with the question of what is being done, but: what is being recognized? I mean «recognize»; grasping something through language or in thought. Can we recognize God? And if so, how? What would that mean? Let's start simpler: Can we recognize this book? ‹Klar. It's right in front of me› now you say. But what if you just dream? Keywords Descartes ‹I do not dream of such a boring theme. › So good. But then I had to dare a journey of thought. I thought: What can you see? It's not just physical objects like the chair I'm sitting on. I also realize that I'm married, although that's nothing physical. I recognize my role in the world, my profession, my social status, my wealth, my intellect, my emotions, my irrationality. I know a lot. But are there also non-recognizable things? Things exist but are inaccessible to us. In my computer science study, I stumbled on such things and this has shocked and fascinated me. There were actually (in this example) numbers that cannot be described. There will never be a numerical system, an artificial intelligence that can all represent these numbers. And there are even infinitely many of them. Small numbers are available and large. I can't call it, because then I would have recognized it, but we know that there are. I tried to follow this thought. What do you know? What is common to these things? It is not matter, because my profession is not matter. It is not the language, because the feelings were before the language. Thus, due to lack of alternatives, I came to the concept of the ‹Muster› .

docs.text: When I say 'Muster', very different things float through your head. Patterns may mean something nice to draw. Geometric figures that are in any regularity. Or someone comes from the intellectual corner and immediately thinks of regularity in nature. These then speak of a pattern when they notice the fact that all planets are not accidentally, but precisely circle around a sun in an ellipse. While the planets themselves are quite randomly in space, the orbit of the planets is by no means random. This ‹non-random› I mean when I talk about patterns. There are things that bear a simplicity in themselves as soon as they have been recognized. Let's consider a baby, for example. His world is small. It consists mainly of his mat, his bed and his mother. When the mother disappears, the world of the infant grows. He cries and expresses with all his abilities the abyss depth despair. When the mother is there and when not, is random for an infant and thus scary and cannot be understood. It must first get an idea that the mother is there, even if she is not felt or smelled. An abstract concept. However, it seems logical and banal to us, but it does not necessarily have to be that. This idea of the continuity of objects is eventually developed by the toddler. It is no longer disturbed when something disappears in a box. The disappearance and emergence of the mother were also much easier to understand and thus to withstand. It found a simplification for this situation, a pattern. This simplification is not intellectually understood. Also not in pictures or language. Rather narrative, so as a story. This story of the mother coming back is comforting. A confusing situation was made clear. An Muster was recognized in the behavior of the mother: it comes back. The pattern already existed before the child who recognized it. But only when it was recognized, it got the ability to calm down. Here is more precise what a pattern is. So that the idea takes shape in you as clearly as possible. Patterns are things that are recognizable, as already said. And what is all recognizable? A lot that can be perceived by the senses: a table, a person, the sky. But even more abstract things: love, joy, mourning. Or ideas like: justice and arbitration. Even more abstract things like: the number two, truth or peace. As you can see from these last examples: patterns are not just things you can perceive. You can't perceive the number two, but you know. She can't be found in the world. Nowhere in the world is the number two and if you destroy them then there is no more the concept of duality. Another note for what is a pattern could be, along with «Muster are all recognizable things» also «Musters are all things that can be described». And if so, then it certainly has no language that can describe abstract things like "the continuity of the mother after her disappearance". But he still recognized the continuity of the mother. Today, however, we usually think in language and it can therefore be useful to define patterns as "all things that can be written". But I do not mean that they can be described at the moment, but they have the ability to be described. We cannot describe the components of a planet that we have not yet discovered. But they are, of course, descriptible. We should just be able to come to this planet. And as it is with all patterns. Life makes this with all the means it has available and we devour it as meaningless. This arrogance is as ridiculous as the tower building to Babel. They believed they built a tower that reaches the gods (12) . The result will also be the same. The groups that declare these deep and sinner-filled experiences as meaningless are not rational. They are just the opposite of rational. The universe speaks so clearly for the sensuality of this experience and we reject it in our intellectual arrogance. It is difficult to say what exactly these experiences are. The amazement in nature or in a concert. Experience the closeness of God. The intuition to pursue a new idea in research. The Muse. But only because I don't know it would be foolish to conclude it was pointless. The result would probably be the fall of a society if you forget and blunt these religious experiences. So meaningfulness is by no means abolished by the acceptance of the evolutionary principle. Existentialism will always remain a marginal phenomenon in society. And if not, we must truly care for our lives. Evolution raises the question. What is the purpose of life? And since we do not see exactly what it takes to keep a society stable, it is not a naive starting point to focus on these sinner-filled states. In addition, a virtuous life is also rewarded. docs.text: This is just a short insert. Patterns have long existed. But all patterns that are subject to the evolutionary process are based on a basic information memory. Nature is based on DNA. The pattern of rudding is not necessarily stored in the genes, but it appears as an emergent pattern from the DNA. However, in the last millennia, as well as in recent years, new information stores have occurred and new evolutionary processes have thus been initiated. The feelings are a precursor of language, but also an abstraction from the judge. Instead of remembering that we did something seemingly wrong when we stroked the sabertooth, the feelings (here the fear) tell us that the judge of the universe has a problem with you when you get close to the tiger. Feelings are a sign of life. Not infallible, but at least a sign. We often remember similar situations with feelings. Our unconscious has saved the link and tells us: ‹This is a nice animal› or ‹This berry is bad›. We share this information store with all animals. And evolution could not work like that if it had not implemented such a premonition of the judgment. It burns an evaluation in our minds and it spreads through imagination, experiences and compassion. Fascinating or recapitulating complex situations is episodic memory. We remember a situation in space and time and play it. We imagine how we flee/fight or promote a partner. We remember similar past situations and think them further or different and we live through them again. This information is extremely intimate, because it does not automatically communicate. But all people have it. The ability to process such information is therefore biologically prevalent. However, the information is hardly accessible to others and therefore only intended for the host. But it is powerful, because we can ‹simulate› the most efficient normal everyday situations. More efficient than allowing us the language, feelings or computers. Stories play with this information store. We tell a story, with a place and a time and we stimulate our episodic memory and store the story there. We are aware that this story has not really happened to us, but it is there and helps us to evaluate situations. The language allows the appearance of completely new patterns: societies of many 1000 people would not be possible without them. This new information store has radically different properties than the DNA. They do not automatically increase, but people have to write books or tell each other stories. It is not only in the individual, but in a library (outsourced information storage). We felt endless space for information. The only question is: what information can and do we want to integrate into our lives? The question also arises: what books are worth preserving? From antiquity, we almost only know the things that have been considered irreplaceable for 2000 years. We don't have diaries, it's the one of the emperors. Even large works of literature, such as other works by Homer, are lost because there was a generation that did not appreciate these texts. This is often done by changing the government. When the Roman Empire disintegrates, the successors often do not invest heavily in preserving the cultural heritage of the predecessors. Thus, many information is lost from one culture to the next. But the history of the information is not completed with the language. The computers have recently been relevant in human history. They are a new kind of information storage, with other laws. Dissemination works differently from DNS and language. Programs can be bought and installed and the information on a hard disk will be changed by their installation alone. Your host is a computer. And similar to the language, the computer is dependent on people. If there were no people who find computers important, they would die. So it's in the interest of the computers to protect people. And that's what happens right now. The computer makes people more powerful than ever. And we have already seen: power is the ability to resist the entropy. So computers enable us to reconfigure the world in an unprecedented way. As we can hardly imagine a humanity without language today, it will soon be with the computers. It is also said by-language: "I don't know how all this should work without the Internet." But this is not literally understood. Humanity would persist without computers, but without language it is difficult. If you let the imagination go a bit, you probably just come up with how humanity would immediately invent a language. But that would be contrary to the thought experiment. Whatever. I only say here that it is as unthinkable in a few decades, perhaps even centuries, without living computers as without language. The soothing thing is: Every person is born without these new-modic things like language and computer. We should not forget: there is a life beyond computers and even beyond language. But the beings without them are less powerful and cannot become so successful against the dangers of nature. So we should not forget that the only justification for language and computer is, evolutionaryly, that they make us more powerful. It's a purely selfish justification. But such a strong reason that it is not to be pointed out from the world.

docs.text: Man is a pattern. We are subject to the 5 points. Every direction we walk as humanity, as a village or as a family, must stand against the court of the universe. docs.text: This finding that all we perceive are patterns and there are laws regarding these patterns is the foundation of my new philosophy. I see myself as a host of different patterns. docs.text: I consider the subject ‹Truth› first because the discussion about it should eliminate a tension that can arise. "How can one build an argument without claiming that there is a truth?" This point of criticism is appropriate. If I say there is no absolute truth (my theory has intentionally never claimed that), then I cannot argue that my theory is correct. The solution of this dilemma is simple, though not necessarily intuitive. If there is no absolute truth, we still have to say what we mean with the term 'truth'. So there is no one. The word 'truth' has a long history, so you can't ignore it. So we will still speak of truth, even if there is no (15) . But I still develop this thought. What did it mean if there is no truth? The world would still work the same way as before, as people still believed there was a truth. And so that these people could accept my theory as ‹tru›, I would have to withstand this game of ‹reference, argument, testing and so on›. I do this and I give ‹ evidence› that convince, then it is accepted as ‹tru›, regardless of the absolute truth. But what if there was an absolute truth? Right away! I would have to play the same game as without and would have to convince the same people of the truth of my theory. I withdraw from an opinion on the existence of absolute truth. Not because I have no opinion, because I have them. It's because my theory is independent of this assumption. My assumption will therefore be: "I do not know whether an absolute truth exists." But how can we discuss the truth here if I withdraw an opinion? We're going a way. Whether there is an absolute truth or not, we can hardly have any direct access to this truth with our limited perception. The only thing we have is the pattern of truth. the idea of truth. This idea is then all we have and what we can talk about, and we will. We will simply consider the truth as a pattern.

docs.text: The truth is one of the dominant patterns in the last centuries. In science everything depends on it. We reject theories and proven things if they are not "true". The pattern of the idea of truth allows a synchronization with the world, which is the reason for its force of enforcement. By truth we understand how the world is real. And if we establish this, we can align our lives in such a way that the universe works for us or at least that we are tolerated by the universe. If faith or knowledge of truth would not allow this, it would never have prevailed. And I argue that precisely this property is the value of truth. The value does not depend on the existence of absolute truth, but on the fact that it allows us to survive. Every synchronization mechanism with the universe is good enough, also it would have penetrated by religious and insane fleas. We have not yet shown sufficient what this idea of truth is. It not only allows us to grasp and analyze facts precisely, but it makes us feel a language that can make predictions. And not just any predictions, but again predictable by truth. Our modern understanding of the truth does not involve any oracles, which can be misunderstood and then make sense at a given time and then become ‹tru›. But if such truths can actually be found against all resistances, then we possess something very powerful. As a result, we become the Oracle of Delphi and can align our decisions with the predictions. And the more precise our language and our understanding of truth becomes, the more powerful we become. This power is an essential part of the manifested survival drive of truth. For every being that exploits this power for itself is superior to others. If I can predict that a tidal wave will come in one day, then I will survive more than the people who cannot anticipate it. And that's why the truth survives. But we have not noticed the almost arrogant of this idea. We do not just claim that such a truth exists. We even claim that it is recognizable. That we can set up hypotheses and test them and if they can withstand these tests, then we call it "true" or something. But we have a strong, but inaudible assumption. For what if the universe plays us a prank. What if things only depend on the laws of nature, because it just wanted God so and when he changes his mind, it will change. All right. At the moment, we believe that Einstein's theory best describes gravity, but that could change again. And what is the truth? We have to be pragmatic.

docs.text: The idea ‹truth› has problems and has to change to survive. Because it will show that much is wrong. We may not reject faith in an absolute truth, but we fundamentally doubt that we can find this truth. But we should not lose this faith without substitution. As I mentioned earlier, the idea of truth must change. From: "This theory is correct." to "This theory is correct enough for now." Newton was never replaced by Einstein. Don't worry, I'm aware of what assumptions I'm seeing and yet I call this step "From being to being". Humes law states that it is impossible to conclude from "being" statements on "desire" statements or vice versa. So from the statement: "I feel uncomfortable" you can't follow: "Great is bad." The evaluation is always the critical aspect in the whole process. Some contradict: "This is ridiculous. I don't care if you can say that philosophically. This is obvious to me." Good, good. I'm asking for some patience. In this book I consistently pass the formal things. Patterns are not well-defined. The 5 points of the evolutionary process are not mathematically precise. It's all a little unprecise, but precise enough to make someone who really is concerned with it notice that the arguments could also be made formally clean. I didn't do that so I wouldn't lose you. But I always tried to keep track of lay people and at the same time not to make any philosophical mistakes. I decided not to make it philosophically precise. But that doesn't mean I couldn't. To follow this path, I have to invest some time and think about this problem. "What causes suffering, so it's bad." These and similar statements are in the criticism of Humes. Because it always remains unclear what the source of ethics is. We can say: "Missing things are unpleasant." But unpleasant has nothing to do with badly. Humes noted that in many texts the authors build long clean arguments and use sentences with building blocks such as «is» or «is not» and then change over to statements such as «soll» or «soll not». He claimed that this change must be argued and will almost never be. He also claims that this little act of attention reproaches all ordinary moral systems. Modern ethics are aware of this problem and meet axiomatic assumptions. So she never claims that from ‹his› follows ‹soll›. She postulates: "Leid is bad" and proceeds from it, then builds up an ethics. However, this assumption is not derived. She's put in the room. In our wealth world, this assumption is shared. I think this conviction comes from the sense of justice. One is convinced that it is not just that others are getting worse and we are trying to help those who are worse. It should be noted here, however, that this assumption "Leid is bad" is not shared globally. Others have an understanding of ‹Ehre› and among them is ‹ehren los› to live badly. These are also willing to suffer for their honor. For these people suffering is in no relation to honor. Again others think a virtuous life is good. They also subordinate the suffering to virtue. Others say that there is no ‹good› and ‹bad›. What I want to show with this is not an argument why Humes law is right. But I just want to point out the fact that the end of ‹ist› has been answered differently across cultures and eras. This does not say that there could be no such conclusion. I'm just trying to get you the problem and make you aware that it's at least not a simple problem. Since the last 100 years, communism or national socialism have often been brought as an argument in this discussion. It is thin ice that I would enter, I said that these systems are according to ‹good›. For one wants to say with all means: "This was bad what was done with the Jews." And it seems to be a common denominator. You don't agree on what moment is a little bad. But that this was bad, you agree. Modern ethics must always be able to compete with Stalin, Mao and Hitler. Mine too. But Humes law remains. And the ballast of our history often makes clear thinking difficult for us. We don't have the courage of Nietzsche. Because one wants to prevent these systems from being relativized. But I am convinced that a philosophy that is afraid of treating unpleasant realities has a difficult state. It would be optimistic to believe that we are pushing the truth with such absolute assumptions. Let us close before such considerations we are no longer on the way of truth, but manifest another pattern and this is a dangerous way (see value of truth). I don't want to relativize this historical event. But it is philosophically difficult to start with such dogmas. It is justified to have such a dogma. But I note that most ethical systems developed after these events are childish from my point of view. They say that reason has to steer. Or that, as I said, suffering is bad. But they often go over just because they want to distance themselves as far as possible from the Nazis, the important and precise considerations that are necessary. I noticed it especially with German philosophers. They commit a philosophical suicide. They already know what they want: "Nazis are bad." And now look for an argument that supports this conclusion. Thinking doesn't work like that. I myself grew up in a conservative-religious environment and there was (of course) believed that God created this earth in 6 days. So they were looking for evidence and found it. No one noticed that the evidence was qualitatively bad, because one was strictly focused on the conclusion. Every proof was right as long as he strengthened his own conviction. And I see the same problem here. I am not talking about saying: "God did not create the world in 6 days." or "Nazis were not so bad at all." From a philosophical point of view, I only have to strongly advise on starting with the conclusion and then bringing them here and then claiming that Nazis are bad. Probably only useless virtue signaling comes out. On the other hand, I think about ethics anew. With the risk of relativizing some dogmas we have. Maybe not. It's impossible to know now. I think it is only intellectually indistinguishable not to leave its place to the most ugly thought. Psychoanalytically speaking: Whoever does not stand up to the monster feeds it. In order to remain philosophically honest, I do not simply accept «Leid is bad» or «Freude is good». These values are not particularly stable over time. So to realize what is good and bad, it is not enough to take such a sentence and then go on. For these two sentences would not have been accepted a few centuries ago. Virtue was more important than joy and suffering. God may be so gracious to give you joy when you behave virtuously, but he does not have to. Jesus also died on the cross and did not escape this path. From the statement «Leids is worse than not suffering» would follow that Jesus would not have acted optimally. But it would hardly be a Christian. He could have suffered less and could have achieved the same. He didn't. They think he did this to prevent a greater suffering, but this image of God is childish. God would have endured and sustained this suffering, even if nothing was achieved. Just because the ‹Gute› is more important than ‹Leid› (17) . The problem with good and bad is therefore quite difficult. There were different assumptions about time. The discussion above is today the most popular, but as I said there are still quite different. Honour, faithfulness to God. Or the purity of the race. The analysis now needs to be evaluated and not a dogma. Note: We are at the transition from Being to Soll. And that's why I just take such anti-human statements as "purity of race". But we will still discover how it is with these statements. The only thing I want to say here is that there were very different ideas about the history of humanity and about the earth, which is good and bad. But in order to get into the field of ethics, I serve an art grip. This is probably exactly the part you can most easily attack in my argumentation. That's it. However, the argument cannot be ignored, because I say it is stronger than all the arguments I had encountered before. And I now consider ethics as patterns and analyze them. What does ethics have to do so that it can exist over time? This discussion will not contribute to the realization of moral truth (18) . As I have already written in the introduction, I see this book in the spirit of Nietzsche: A search for wisdom and not truth beyond good and evil. So we will analyze existent ethics. We'll be able to compare them. And I am aware that all these analyses do not contribute to absolute moral value. But an ethics that does not withstand the evolutionary principle disappears is irrelevant in practice. Whether the objectively correct ethics (if there is one) is among these possible ethics, I don't care. Because it would be just wishful thinking and would have nothing to do with reality. So instead of carrying out the transition from being to being, I consider all the ethics that can exist. And they will also check if they can have stock. An ethics include a collection of ‹Soll› statements. If these ‹Soll› statements are followed, one speaks of ‹good› trading. However, there are different views, which involves good action. They contradict each other in a certain way. The ones think that one must eradicate evil from the world, the others think that one must cure it, others choose an intermediate path. And this is just one of countless examples. But instead of attempting any axiomatic/dogmatic argument, we can now consider the general pattern of ethics. What does an ethics have to do to last the time? Or also, how does an ethics change: how does it change the judge and how is it changed by the judge. We'll see how much free space we still have after the analysis. Whether any action can actually be legitimized or whether it is practically absolute (19) Values are derived. If so, this would be an interesting beginning for an undogmatic ethics (20) .

docs.text: Ethics is a codex as I said. This must be recorded on an information memory, otherwise it cannot be detected and followed. These memories are different: In a law, it's a law book. In conscience it is our brain (21) . And there are also unpronounced rules of conduct in communities. These are interpersonally stored. This is then more an ethics that originated from other patterns, but also such a pattern is ultimately only one pattern on other patterns and follows the evolutionary principle quite normal. You notice that all ethics are a normal pattern. It is similar to ethics with truth. Whether an absolute truth exists now became irrelevant to us. We only looked at our idea of truth. And the same is what we are going to do here. Whether an absolute morale exists is irrelevant. It is only important in practice whether ethics can survive or not. I look at ethics by way of example. Namely cliché village sites. So I mean such rules as: "A wedding in the village brings every (22) a self-made bread." or "The woman has no right to object to the man." You could list more rules here. It is irrelevant whether such a village exists in reality with these rules. It's just you can imagine. (23) In this case, these rules are not recorded in a text. Neither an individual is the reference for the rules. It is not that a person can say at once: "From today we do it differently." For the rules are distributed over the members of the Community. The rules are stable as people do not like to change and these rules are seen as self-evident. You also have a judge. You must assert yourself against all the new ideas of members. Against traditions that come from outside. And they can lose. Hardly anything from all of this has existence for eternity. I hope it is clear that even such a complex as villagers is a normal ethics that must behave like all patterns. It may or may not have an inventory. Next we need to clarify why there is such a pattern as ethics. It is a pattern that exists as far as we can look back. There were always rules of conduct. It acts as if it were not possible to build a society without an ethics, without rules of conduct. Or, in other words, groups with rules of conduct override groups without rules. The rules help the group to survive and a surviving group allows the rules to continue. So the argument is not: it is impossible to think a group without rules. One such group is one with rules. This follows: The question is no longer: «Why is there ethics?», but: «Why is this ethics?» An ethics that persist over time must be stable. A pattern must always protect the information carrier. The DNA is interested in the fact that the living being by being survived. Thus, ethics are equally interested in the survival of the people they host; and also replant. An ethics therefore have different goals: it wants to be stably anchored in its host. She wants to be multiplied or at least not extinct. So for example, she wants her own children to take over her or that others turn to her. And when I speak of ‹Willen› of ethics, I do not mean that ethics have a ‹Will› meaning in the literal (metaphysical) sense. It is a fact that an ethics that manifests a behavior that is similar to this ‹Willen› will prevail.

docs.text: Instead of analysing what is possible, I let myself inspire myself from the history and specifically from religions. It is something dared, but over a long time religion and ethics were not exactly different. The gods said what is good and bad. Therefore, in the history of ethics it is necessary to consider the history of religion. First there are the tribal systems: My trunk is good, your bad. I have to fight you, with violence. Careful duties exist above all to those of their own tribe. In such systems, ethics are bound to another pattern. To the tribe. The success stands and falls with him. However, other ethics can spread better. To date, Judaism is still deeply influenced by this thinking. Jewish ethics are strongly linked to the Jewish population. It stabilizes through the Diaspora. When the Jews are scattered over the world, but have a strong bond to their origin, they are remarkably stable. If only one country lived by all the Jews, then the risk would be greater for a disappearance in the event of a lost war or another disaster. However, there are other ways of thinking: there are many-Völker states soon. Actually, something like an EU only with violence. The Romans subjugated other peoples and allowed local laws and gods as long as the Roman laws and gods were higher valued. To this end, the laws and gods of Rome had to leave free space. Not everything must be regulated. This flexibility in dealing with new rules and gods allows the Roman system to adapt to new circumstances. However, there must be enough structure. Enough hardness and power to enforce the hierarchy of laws and gods. This creates a highly complex system. They were not the only, but the best documented. It was a true multicultural empire. And this is probably the most successful to date. I'm just going into our dilemma today. With today's mobility, a mixing of cultures is made possible, as never before in human history. In addition, the awareness that other cultures are also valid systems. This is followed by the tendency not to force a single person to his own culture. From a historical perspective, this is negligent. We feel obliged because we have done unjust things in other countries. I believe, however, that the chance is high that it will be a serious mistake not to put our own culture in your own country/area over the culture of the immigrants. How much free space is left to the immigrant cultures is then a difficult, hard and necessary debate that must be conducted. (24) There are rules of conduct that spread independently of the political structure. They exist only in the minds and can be believed and lived out by Germans, Japanese and Ethiopia. They spread and take land. But not literally, but in the heads. The dominant systems nowadays are the same. Christianity, capitalism, humanism, atheistic Buddhism. They are all ways of thinking that fight for domination in the minds. Some are combinable, others are not easy. You've managed to solve more and more of the geography. Thus, they are not readily erased. These imperial or even evangelizing systems will probably always exist in a globalized world, and from my point of view it is interesting only that can and will prevail and which are not. Ethics always solves the same problem from my point of view: How can I trust someone I don't know? Or even more fundamental: How can I know what the other wants? An ethical system sets limits and those that follow the same system move within the system. It creates confidence. I could live at a couple of pastors during my study period. They read me into their apartment. And why? Because I was a Christian of similar denomination. Not only about it, but also. They trusted me very quickly because they knew I'd stick to similar rules as they did. But how do we manage to adhere to such rules, although it would be advantageous to break them according to the situation? We have stories. We say, God has given us these rules. Or we say, everyone has an inviolable dignity. Or we say, you've always done that. These are all stories that help us take the rules seriously. But ultimately it is not the stories, but the faith that helps us to follow the ethics. We believe that the rules are important. Therefore, humanism and atheistic ethics have a challenge to themselves; because they would often rather abolish or at least ignore faith as such. And religions have perfected that. Faith is an explicit resource there. Trust in something you don't see. Faith is encouraged: It is evident that the atheistic and agnostic ethics could have problems if they do not discover this fact for themselves. Maybe they can ride on the shoulders of religion. In religion, people learn to believe, and then they apply this faith to godless things. Maybe. But this is a dangerous strategy. Especially if you saw at the same time the foundations of religion. The last thing we still lack is the actual conditions under which ethics can continue. Ethics is not (only) described in the DNA, but also in our thoughts. In the conscious considerations and the unconscious ‹Trieben›. In our instincts and our relationship with other people. So it's a highly complex thing. All these information stores influence ethics. If one falls away, it changes and it has to compensate for it. In order for an ethics to be established, it must take care of its bearers. A comprehensive and selfless ethics have made it difficult, as it evolves and is based on itself by the destruction of the host. An narcissistic egoism, however, is also not targeted, although this would be a beginning. In egoism, as I said, the problem is that it does not exist against a group that behaves in solidarity. Ethics must bear the concern they want to shape. A tribal ethics should take care of the tribe and thus also to its own members, at least so good that it survives and continues ethics. Another tactics is the spread of ethics as a survival strategy. This is the recipe of early Christianity (and every new religion). The first disciples of Jesus were commissioned: "Go out into the world and make all men disciples." From today's point of view, this order is like to be criticized, but our glasses of the patterns analyze this completely neutral: proliferation is one of the best strategies for a pattern to persist. With the increase, ethics can also afford selflessness. And a spreading, self-sacrific ethics is quite viral and stable at the same time. Consider how revolutionary this is. Such an ethics is a pattern that works successfully against the ‹Selfish gene›. Its own distribution is more important than the genes. Missioning makes no sense genetically, but ethically very well. Every person has his own ethics. A code of conduct. This is influenced by education, genes, conscience, expectations of others, intellectual considerations and even more. The point I want to get out of here is: A personal Christian ethics is not the same pattern as Christianity itself. My personal ethics is only a manifestation of Christianity. The personal view then has conflicts of interest. More precisely, there are different patterns that manifest a survival drive. I want to survive at the same time, but my Christian ethics want self-tasting for a higher good. Christianity can only prevail if it is possible to consolidate this self-tasting among individual persons. This has chosen the hardest opponent in the invigorated universe: the survival drive of the gene. This requires extraordinary stories. A ‹let› that claims that there is a reward after death, for example. Or that life here on earth has an influence on life in eternity. These ‹slides› must be believed so strongly that it resists reality. Don't let the ‹truth› drive out. Only in this way can self-tasting manifest itself. The crazy thing is that ethics now prefer those genes that believe such a ‹lust›. And if ethics have an influence on the choice of partners, then also on the genes. That religions have done this is amazing and by no means obvious.

docs.text: With all our thoughts on patterns and ethics, we are ready to describe a stable ethics without designing unrealistic utopias. I don't want to develop ethics that like a virus spreads across all people and displaces everything else, but interest me in what direction we should develop. In which direction we must move our beliefs and ethical standards. This direction can itself be considered an ethics. Or more precise than ‹Meta› ethics. Since she talks about the development of ethics. There are different angles of view to capture a situation. Since ethics consist of a collection of individual ethics, one has to consider both. What is, measured in the evolutionary process, meaningful behavior for an individual, for a family, for a village, for a country, for a whole ethics. If they agree, then we have something that will almost certainly happen, or at least should. To now look at these levels, we find that it needs two factors to survive an ethics. Stability and continuity. Stability is just another word for something to survive. Stable are things that resist the environment and history. And continuity means that the changes are only continuing. For if it goes too fast, one can almost no longer speak of the same ethics, but has a new ethics which has not yet proved their stability. Next we will address these points more precisely before we look at ethics. In ethical discussions, the concept of stability has often arisen. But it hardly even played an important role. Only system philosophers such as Luhmann and Parsons have given their special status to me. The glasses of the patterns added to the systemic thinking. Patterns resist destabilization with all their strength. They do not really resist, but the patterns that manifest a ‹simultaneous› behavior are more persevering the time. From now on I will speak about ethics as an active thing and say: "The ethics do this or that." I do not mean that she really does this, but that she manifests such a behavior and would not do that, if she were consecrated to the decline. So an ethics are vehemently against destabilization. "Every empire that is unincorporated with itself is devastated; and any city or house that is unincorporated with itself will not exist. (25) » It does not have to be one in terms of the spoken, thoughtful or philosopher, but only with regard to the negotiated or the manifested. As long as a group cooperates in their deeds and stabilizes the group, it is irrelevant whether they are also in thought one. For example, different religious confess to the same dogma for belief, others for social considerations again confess themselves for habit and for reflexive psychological reasons. If the group is one with respect to vocabulary and deeds, that is sufficient. Thus the religious under faith understands an inner conviction related to a metaphysical truth. Those who believe in habit mean that you hunt the dogmas. And the social considerations also mean the affirmation of dogmas, but with the awareness that this affirmation strengthens cohesion. And lastly, the psychologically-interested person understands by faith a psychological effect which is necessary to exercise religion. These fundamentally different approaches are nevertheless almost completely compatible and therefore compatible in a group. The group must only be stable in the sense that, as mentioned, they agree on deeds and vocabulary. But what social values must be one? All: The country must take care of the political institutions and the localities and the state workers and taxpayers and residents. This must not be romanticized: worrying is something nice said: not killing and indoctrinating would be sufficient under certain circumstances. And it must also influence the individual ethics so that the great ethics remain. This is a challenge. The settings on all levels must be compatible. The attitude of politics must be coexist with the attitudes of individuals, so they can strengthen each other and work in synergy. These levels of ethics can be considered individually. This is how we start with individual ethics. So this is what you or I personally consider to be "good" and "bad". This appreciation, contrary to the opinion of some thinkers, is at most limited under our control. It is closely linked to conscience. The conscience is a pattern rooted in emotions and only laboriously and limitedly accessible to the mind. It is a manifestation of different ethics that influence the individual; some from ancient times and others from the present. Some influences are aware, others are not. A person can therefore unite enlightening values and a fundamentalist religion. This then obviously gives tensions. However, they do not have to be dissolved. It often seems good enough for an ethics if it can live out at least at certain moments. In the Church fundamentalism and at work the enlightened spirit. While changing the contexts requires energy, it is possible. And that also over a longer time. The tension is often approached and eliminated after a few years. If this is not done, one calls such a person ‹unauthentic›. Which means as much as the person is not ‹real›. So that the person carries contradictions in himself and does not consciously affect him. This urge for authenticity causes some to eliminate the contradictions. This dismantling is done either by a merger: insights from the fundamentalist period are formulated in detail. Or the one pushes the other. However, this makes one of the habitats more unpleasant. If you let go of enlightening thinking, it can have an influence on careers and vice versa on church life. However, no matter how to solve it: these changes are then carried back into the groups. And change the group ethics there. Maybe not in the desired way, but every individual ethics also changes the group ethics. Thus, an introduced enlightenment value into the Church can activate the protective mechanism of the Church and cause a hardening and radicalization of the group ethics. What is also a change. The point is not that an individual can influence the group ethics as it wishes. It is a fact that an individual always influences group ethics as long as it interacts with it (26) . Disgusting ethics can be accommodated in one and the same person as we have all experienced. The psyche is the place where things change, because it is the greatest power of thought known to us in the universe. And as much as we tend to condemn the contradictory side, the anti-national right, or the ‹value-earning left›, there is only a real change when the opposite side gains space in our own thoughts. Only when the contradictory views give themselves a duel in their own head is what is generally referred to as 'thinking'. And this only if no straw doll version of the opposite side is used. In order to resolve this tension, a 'dialogue' is often sought between the parties. Because others have the same tension in their head. This is intended if one of the speakers or listeners seriously takes up the views of others. A discussion is often only for the listeners. The debaters on stage do not move in any direction. Because they are attacked by outside. They therefore feel legitimate to refuse. However, if the attack comes from the inside: so you leave the conflicting thoughts room, then there is a fight in your head. Only in this state is learning, thinking and changing possible. To demand this from the opposite side is not acceptable to us. We can only do it ourselves. Fingering that the ‹externally anti-rights› are the only way to think about the cohesion of their own group or as a defence mechanism. But thinking and change is only possible if one lets the ‹external› thoughts into oneself. But what world citizen is brave enough for it. But is that an imperative? Does an individual truly think? We are in the early age of globalisation. Not because it is so new, but because the cultural struggles have not yet been completed. Cultures and ethics are just as testified in the Cold War. In contrast to the Cold War, the fronts are not clear and the struggle takes place in the individual. The individual must find (s) a way to deal with this plurality. And I say: to shape and adapt your own ethics so that it is compatible with this world, is necessary. In this way, fundamentalists must provide access to science so that they are not psychologically, economically and technologically suspended. The technocrats have to give enough room to the psychological stability factors, otherwise they flood a wave of the unspoiled psychological unconscious overburden. The anesthesia of such phenomena through: ‹videos look›, ‹chatten›, ‹scroll› or on the other hand: ‹loss in the Bible or God› are not permanent solutions. They are merely a deceleration of what happens anyway: that reality collapses: in the form of a depression, a non-afterage or alienation. To circumvent the question of the imperative, I say here this: only the individuals who manage to adapt to reality will last time. Only the ethics that are so flexible to adapt will last time. A single person is so short-lived that it is conceivable that he never concerns the contradictions. But what if I find fit ‹bad›. Then follows a simple consideration. The patterns ‹good› and ‹bad› are also subject to the evolutionary process. In order not to draw the anger of all moral absolutists on me here: I specify: Our conception of ‹good› and ‹bad› is subject to the evolutionary process. With this formulation I leave the door open for any absolute moral values. However, recognition of this is also controlled by the evolutionary process. Only the values that can prevail. But they do not ‹confuse› controlled by the evolutionary process› with ‹wilful›. Because only the ideas of 'good and evil' can prevail, which are viable. And it is probably that in a globalized world the values are pushed towards tolerance and directed more inward in a national world. Whether inward-looking values or externally directed values are going through depends essentially on the development of political systems. For man reacts to change with rationalization and other intellectual processes. This is a revolution of causality. They say that the values determine politics. But it seems that politics affects the values. We are looking for reasons that explain why democracy is good, for example. Precisely considered as a pattern, it is a mutual influence. Nevertheless, our ideas of ‹good› and ‹böse› are not static, because they adapt. This knowledge sounds relativistic. But it's not perfect. Not all values can exist. Note that it is always a fight for survival. Both for world views and for people. As long as societies exist side by side and networking is only small, they can have different values. Thus, cannibals and conscientious dictators can exist alongside more moderate regions. But time will dominate a view. The rich will be gathered together and the most stable rich will last the time. This is why we still have the values of ancient Rome as a foundation for our values. Because they were so dominant, not because they were closer to absolute moral values. But the values of an empire are by no means arbitrary. Not every policy and worldview is able to support an empire. A question that exceeds this book is: what values have the best chances of survival in which situations? What are the attitudes that can be oriented towards the future? I will make here concrete and now the linguistic leap to a concrete ethics. And as I have always said before, if you are to do this or that, then I mean that such a behavior (muster) offers greater chances of survival. In summary, one can say that action depends on the information storage of ethics. If we had no language, another action would be right. Because not all ethical standards can be manifested without language. Without language, the right action is primarily concerned with genes. With the language, but also strong with memes and communication. Each person is a manifestation of ideas and it is our task to preserve, adapt and pass on them. Which of all these ideas should be prioritized? All that is rated as viable. But you do not forget the inner shoots. They influence what we consider important. One might say that the consequence of this thinking is: do what you think is correct. But if you are particularly smart, then think: what, of what you think right, could be improved? How? How could you stabilise yourself better? Or better said: How are you most stable so that you can host your patterns in the future? Let's consider a specific question: should I behave nicely, even in a bad place, with the safe prospect of death? Absolutely! Because the only surviving pattern that you might be able to save in the future is that you made a difference in the impossible situation. One example: Alexander Solzhenizyn wrote about the gulag and all the torture methods there. The inhumanity of the guards, officials and also inmates were spread out by him most accurately and clearly before the reader. But the light looks in such a story have potential for inspiration that it is not to ignore. A nun who was raped again and again, but did not break. Strong. And the guards looked sorry. That nun stayed in my head. I want to be like her. Their pattern of self-sacrification is so contagious and impressive that it overcame generations, genders and language barriers and pushed into my head. None of the rapists did this to me. Not even close. And how many have beenhaved virtuously and have been forgotten? Much too many, but still in such a situation this is probably the only right thing. Self-protection is also a valid goal. And from this, the inhumanities of the inmates emerged. But the self-employed have sacrificed much for their survival. They lost their humanity and can be grateful to God if they survived that there are psychological mechanisms such as displacement and oblivion. I'm not teaching those already punished. What happened to me! But us. We're not in the gulag. What kind of person does this stupidity exist? What qualities do I have to develop to create it as a human being from a gulag? What is my foundation? What's stopping in the free fall? This is the important question instead of playing ‹good› against ‹bad›. But what if we make progress on these thoughts? If we decide what kind of things we can do. Be it intellectual, spiritual or abdominal. What do we do with this progress? The only thing we can do is pass on. Whether it's our thoughts, feelings or genes. And we have to set ourselves up to make this possible. It's the only way an ethics can survive. But does this view not promote co-currence? A passivity? Doesn't this mean an attitude: "We don't change anything and keep the old values?", because we want to pass on the patterns of our ancestors to our children. To some extent, but only as much as possible. We strive for existence. Every pattern in us. But in order to continue to exist, we must always assert ourselves against all others who want to exist. To keep our village, we have to go with time and not let ourselves hang. At the same time, we must not erode the values that stabilize us. In a progressive period, however, this is the opposite of a conservative message in a conservative period. You could say it's a moderate message.
